4 \section solarflare-onload Solarflare Onload
5 
6 Solarflare Onload is a sockets acceleration technology for the transparent acceleration of sockets-based applications.
7 
8 \details
9 
10 On Linux, the Handler uses [Solarflare Onload](https://solarflare.com/onload/) Extensions API to support additional
11 features of Solarflare network cards.
12 If one uses such network cards, in your system, you can benefit from advanced features of such network cards.
13 B3 BOE Handler automatically detects if the corresponding Onload library installed in your system and, if so,
14 then loads it in run-time and provides an ability to use additional features.
15 In this case, there should be the record, in the Handler log, that the corresponding version of the Onload extension
16 library is used.
17 
18 \note If one wants to test Onload features on the loopback network interface, `EF_TCP_CLIENT_LOOPBACK` and
19 `EF_TCP_SERVER_LOOPBACK` parameters should be used,
20 e.g.: `EF_TCP_CLIENT_LOOPBACK=2 EF_TCP_SERVER_LOOPBACK=2 onload ..`.
21 
22 Please see the "Onload User Guide".
23 
24 Currently, the Handler supports the following Onload features:
25 
26 - Onload message warmup
27 
28 When one uses the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::warmUp method, the Handler automatically enables this feature.
29 As a result, one can get the maximal warm-up effect, including the complete warm-up of the TCP stack's sending path.
30 
31 The `onload_stackdump` utility could be used to monitor the usage of this feature.
32 
33 For example:
34 
35  onload_stackdump lots | grep warm
36

39 \section tcpdirect Solarflare TCPDirect
40 
41 Solarflare TCPDirect is an ultra-low latency network stack.
42 
43 
44 \subsection tcpdirect-stack-creation Creating OnixS TcpDirectStack
45 
46 Before TCPDirect sessions can be created, the application must first create a TCPDirect stack
47 (OnixS::B3::BOE::TcpDirectStack):
48 \snippet TCPDirect.cpp createStack
49 
50 Attributes (OnixS::B3::BOE::TcpDirectAttr) control the configuration of the stack and its behavior, please see the
51 Solarflare TCPDirect User Guide
52 for a complete list of available attributes and their description.
53 
54 TCPDirect sessions should be created in the same thread where TcpDirectStack has been created.
55 The reference to the stack is provided in Session's constructor, for example:
56 \snippet TCPDirect.cpp createSession
57 
58 By default, each TCPDirect stack can handle up to 64 TCP endpoints, so those number of sessions could be created.
59 Maximum number of TCP endpoints can be set by `max_tcp_endpoints` attribute.
60 Please refer to Solarflare TCPDirect documentation.
61 See also `max_tcp_listen_endpoints`, `max_tcp_syn_backlog`, `max_udp_rx_endpoints`, `max_udp_tx_endpoints` attributes.
62 These attributes could be set to a minimum value to save hardware and software resources.
63 
64 
65 \subsection tcpdirect-event-loop Dispatching network events, asynchronous connect and disconnect
66 
67 External code on top of TCPDirect can be implemented as an event loop.
68 
69 The need to scroll through the loop means the inability to use blocking calls because blocking calls will stop
70 the event's dispatching. Therefore, user code must call asynchronous Session's methods to connect and disconnect, for
71 example:
72 \snippet TCPDirect.cpp dispatching
73 
74 
75 \subsection tcpdirect-stack-shutdown TcpDirectStack shutdown
76 
77 In general, TCPDirect stack requires to finish all outstanding work and to handle all outstanding events.
78 Before destroying the TcpDirectStack instance, the following code should be executed:
79 \snippet TCPDirect.cpp ensureQuiescent
80 
81 Method `TcpDirectStack::isQuiescent()` (OnixS::B3::BOE::TcpDirectStack::isQuiescent) returns a boolean value indicating
82 whether a stack is quiescent.
83 
84 This can be used to ensure that all connections have been closed gracefully before destroying a stack (or exiting the
85 application). Destroying a stack while it is not quiescent is permitted by the API, but when doing so there is no
86 guarantee
87 that sent data has been acknowledged by the peer or even transmitted, and there is the possibility that peers'
88 connections will be reset.
89 
90 \subsection tcpdirect-threading-model TCPDirect threading model
91 
92 \warning Access to the stack instance at each moment is possible from only **one** thread. The TCPDirect middle-ware
93 does **not** use inter-threaded synchronization, does **not** serialize calls, and does **not** check the correctness of
94 access to its API by the user.
95 Therefore, **the event dispatching and message sending should be performed from the same thread**.
96 
97 \subsection tcpdirect-emulator TCPDirect emulator for Windows
98 
99 The TCPDirect API does not support loopback connections as opposed to regular sockets.
100 
101 To facilitate the development and debugging of applications based on TCPDirect OnixS B3 BOE Handler contains the
102 TCPDirect emulator
103 for Windows on top of regular sockets with call correctness verification.
104 
105 Unlike the original technology, the TCPDirect emulator allows you to create a loopback connection, which also helps the
106 application debugging process.
107 
108 TCPDirect emulator does not require additional configuration, it activated automatically under Windows when
109 TcpDirectStack object is created and used.
110 
111 Native TCPDirect-connections should belong to the corresponding Solarflare hardware interface. In Windows emulation mode
112 it could be any existing network
113 interface that allows binding the sockets to it. In most common debugging scenarios is recommended to use the same
114 interface (and its IP address) both for
115 an exchange emulator (OnixS::B3::BOE::Testing::Gateway) and TCPDirect-emulated client connection.
116 
117 \warning Under Windows TCPDirect emulator, destroying a stack while it is not quiescent may cause a memory leak.
118 
119 \see \ref tcp-direct-getting-started-sample
120 \see \ref tcp-direct-benchmark-sample
